results.title: Melbourne rising
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Sam De Silva and SKA TV
results.brief_description: ‘Melbourne Rising’ is a video document about the S11 protests against the World Economic Forum at Crown Casino in Melbourne. The protests aimed to shut down the summit in opposition to the injustices of corporate driven globalisation. After its release in late September 2000, Melbourne Rising was screened and broadcast in Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, Italy, the Neteherlands, New Zealand, Switzerland, the UK and the USA. It also featured in numerous film festivals across Australia as well as Korea and India.

results.title: BabaKiueria
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: In the mind of the architect. Ep. 1. Keeping the faith
results.creator_credit: Tim Clark, Janne Ryan and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
A stylish exploration into the eclectic world of architects and their cutting edge creations. Concentrating on the views and motivations of several award-winning architects and a selection of their most remarkable and challenging projects, this series sets out to explain the process we call architecture - its philosophy and its essential relationship with people.
Music composed and performed by The Necks.

results.title: Driving home
results.brief_description:
A child is being driven through a real and imaginary landscape. We experience her subtle turmoil as she tries to make sense of these worlds.
This beautiful animation depicts the sense of disorientation and isolation felt by a young girl who is a recent immigrant of Australia. The quintessentially Australian backdrop of the wide open road serves to add to her mental and physical unease. The emotional confusion that is expressed in the narrative is realised perfectly in the shifting, sweeping motion of the oil paint animation. MIFF 2000

results.title: Bsss
results.brief_description: A fly meets an elephant…by the book! A fly buzzes around a room landing upon a book with pictures of an elephant inside. The fly appears to investigate the drawing. A human squashes the fly into the book. Fly and elephant are united. (Screened at MISAF, October 2000.)

results.title: Lazy Sunday afternoon
results.brief_description: In the desert a vulture enjoys the silence of a hot afternoon. The sudden appearance of a vehicle destroys the quiet of the day. Two pistoleros exit the car ready for a duel; our hero, the vulture, watches as the pistoleros take part in a very funny slow motion shoot-out.

results.title: Robots: the animated docu-soap
results.brief_description:
Just another day in the life of three ordinary robots suffering for their art - Jackson, a painter/sculptor; Roland, a composer/musician; and Hands, a champion skater. This award-winning animated film tracks the demise of the three redundant robots as they attempt to reassert meaning into their empty lives. Made in the style of a documentary-soap and containing a rather dark sense of humour, this is a somewhat offbeat satirical depiction of the genre.
Voice: David Hopewell. (Awards: Best New British Animation, Edinburgh International Film Festival 2000; Jury Award, Art Film Festival 2001)

holdings.name: MPEG-2 Digital File; Memory Grid Pod Full Encode

results.brief_description: A memory film set in Belfast in 1981 during the IRA hunger strikes which led to the death and eventual martyrdom of Bobby Sands. Quiet and powerful, ‘81’ contains multiple points of view, alternating between Catholic and Protestant, women and men, youth and adults. What lingers and what haunts are the vivid stark images of the prisoners’ gaunt faces on the television sets; the determined set of Thatcher’s jaw; Bobby Sands’ eyes staring out from the posters glued haphazardly on the Belfast streets.

results.title: Dottie gets spanked
results.brief_description: Todd Haynes’ black comedy is set in 1950s suburbia where the TV heroine Dottie reigns supreme. When a young boy gets his chance to meet his idol, the series of events he witnesses transforms his fantasy life. This is where childhood’s end begins.
